sn3.9:4.2: Now at that time a big sacrifice had been set up for King Pasenadi of Kosala. Five hundred chief bulls, five hundred bullocks, five hundred heifers, five hundred goats, and five hundred rams had been led to the pillar for the sacrifice.
sn3.9:4.3: His slaves, servants, and workers did their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.
sn3.9:5.1: Then several mendicants got dressed in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn3.9:5.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha,
sn3.9:5.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn3.9:5.4: and told him what was happening.
sn3.9:6.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:
sn3.9:7.4: these huge violent sacrifices yield no great fruit.
sn3.9:8.1: The great sages of good conduct
sn3.9:9.1: But the great sages of good conduct
sn3.9:10.1: A clever person should sacrifice like this,
sn3.9:10.2: for this sacrifice is very fruitful.
sn3.9:10.3: For a sponsor of sacrifices like this,
sn3.9:10.5: Such a sacrifice is truly abundant,
sn3.9:10.6: and even the gods are pleased.”
